Ed china. The man can attach an engine to pretty much anything and has the balls to test them out himself.

Michael Palin Britain's nicest man. A great ambassador for travel. Incredible performances and comedy writing throughout the Monty Python series and films, and a few other bits and pieces. Edit - Probably my favourite thing about the man, apart from the way he interacts on his travels, is the fact he can't seem to keep a straight face on stage. He's clearly smirking in the 'Biggus Dickus' scene, which makes me wonder how many takes they did before giving up and using that one.
Some of the great documentary makers seem like really wonderful inspiring people. Jem Stanfield from bang goes the theory. Helen Czerski Alice Roberts Hannah Fry Mark Miodownik Sim Oakley
For their pioneering British space efforts, I would like to add both Helen Sharman and Tim Peake into the mix.
Dame Jane Goodall, Chimpanzee expert and wildlife conservationist.
David Olusoga. Academic, author and TV presenter.
The Wealdstone Raider
Tim Berners-Lee. Without him we mightn't be using reddit.
Floella Benjamin
Adam Curtis I could watch his documentaries over and over. So informative and insightful but entertaining too. A true original filmmaker.
Jacqueline Wilson - her books were my childhood and she wrote about so many different issues that parents/children/families go through in such a gentle way.
To me I'd say Sir David attenborough for obvious reasons and Stephen fry I love watching QI.
Iâ€™m not sure how to express it but Harry Hill has always inspired me.

Frank Bruno, maybe not the best boxer of all time though he did shine at one point. But his suffering with mental health issues and his openness about it and willing to help others it great. He's also completely unpretentious and makes everyone around him feel relaxed. And that laugh is just gold, god bless you sir.
Sir Ranulph Fiennes is a complete badass.
Ronnie Pickering.
Always found Sir Alex Ferguson to be pretty inspirational. Even if you hate Man Utd youâ€™ve kind of got to respect his commitment and indefatigable spirit.
Martin Lewis. The money saving expert guy. He's very underappreciated in my opinion. And has saved me many thousands with his help/tips. To me, he genuinely feels like he cares about people.

I don't know enough about him to know if he's all good but I find James Timpson's (of Timpson's the cobblers) approach of training and hiring prison-leavers/ex-convicts inspiring. Giving people a second chance is very powerful (and also reduces the risk of reoffending).

Not a particularly famous guy, but Charles Cockell, professor of astrobiology at the University of Edinburgh. He went to some of the worst prisons in Scotland and taught a course there encouraging the inmates to design a moon/Mars base. The designs were published in a book and they were genuinely impressive. He also stood against John Major as a candidate for the Forward to Mars Party. He had a really cool lecture series during the pandemic: https://youtube.com/channel/UCBTwJSnAqZZczK7stBaYq5w

Surprised nobody's mentioned Iron Maiden's Bruce Dickinson yet. * he was a good enough fencer to be considered for the British Olympic squad in his youth. * Frontman of one of the biggest metal bands on the planet, obvs. * Learns to fly in his spare time. Works for a commercial airline. Ends up being type certified on the Boeing 747 so he can fly Maiden on tour. * [Tried (and failed) to crash an Airbus A320 in his documentary series "Flying Heavy Metal"](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IKBABNL-DDM) * Owns an aircraft maintenance company in Cardiff. * [Supporter of the "Vote Bean" campaign in 1992.](https://www.reddit.com/r/ironmaiden/comments/srt4fl/vote_bean/)
Sir David Attenborough.
Another one for Sir Alex Ferguson. Smart, inspires people around him, humble yet ruthless. Imagine what could be done if he had run the country instead.
I am, I'm still here, working my ass off, paying my bills.
Rick Astley, because heâ€™s never gonna give you, let you down, turn around and desert you.
Del boy, always wheeling and dealing, ducking and diving. He's a famous import export dealer in south London.
I know this is random but Brian Cox, the amazing gift he had of not only story telling but educating people of different levels of knowledge, seems like a beautiful person.

Riz Ahmed. He's not only an amazing actor but he's absolutely smashing the mainstream stereotype of what Muslims/British Pakistani roles are on screen and behind them. Marcus Rashford, for everything. He's a role model for those who don't care about the beautiful game. Jacqueline McKenzie the human rights/Windrush lawyer. Ian McKellen (& Patrick Stewart as a side) for his on/off screen stuff for gay rights and the beautiful friendship he has with Stewart is everything anti toxic masculinity.

Elton John. He's not everybody's cup of tea, but the man is a solidified icon, for multiple reasons. He & Bernie Taupin have created some of the best known songs in the English language, brought to life by Elton's virtuosic skills with piano & vocals. On top of that, he's also one of the greatest LGBTQ+ icons to date. It took balls to be as flagrant with his identity back when he came out, especially as high-profile as he was. I say this as a heterosexual man, not for internet points or to virtue-signal, but purely to make my perspective clear to any readers. Sure, you can talk about his wealth & wealth inequality, but that's another can of worms & frankly, there's plenty of bigger fish to fry in that pond. Anyway, yeah, global treasure, let alone national.

I remeber watching the 2012 olympics and being struck at how full of life Nicola Adams was. I really like how happy she is and I find her story really inspiring. Whenever I see her on TV she always brings a big daft smile to my face ðŸ˜Š

Sir David Attenborough. He's brought the wonders of the natural world to millions. Inspiring people to pay more attention to life and it's beauty. The dude is in his 90s and still kicking it. He is one of the most well loved and treasured people in the world, let alone the UK.
Brian May An enthusiast for everything righteous, a sympathetic and sincere challenger to a cause and an inspirational rock god

Charlotte Worthington. Olympic freestyle BMX gold medalist. She absolutely smashed it despite not really being seen as a contender for gold by pulling a trick never seen in womanâ€™s competition before. Put Female riders from the UK on the map, seeing lots of women take up BMX as a result in what is usually a heavily male dominated sport.
Mo Farah. Went from a Somali refugee to a world beating athlete and seems like such a nice guy too.

**Michael Sheen** - actor and activist - has become a "not-for-profit actor". He sold his houses to ensure the 2019 Homeless World Cup went ahead in Cardiff and has pledged to carry on using the money he earns from acting to fund more projects.

Jack Monroe - lived off food banks and created a blog for cheap and easy meals for people on a low income, eventually earning their way out of poverty and publishing their own cookbooks. Recently they managed to put pressure on Asda to reintroduce its Smart Price range in all stores (Asda have been slowly reducing the range and removing it from some stores). They're now working on the Vimes Boot Index to show a realistic measure of inflation (as the RPI doesn't accurately reflect the price impact of lower priced goods that many low income people rely upon). During lockdowns they also fought for better free school meals for children.
Marcus Rashford, Manchester Utd and England who raised the plight of poor children going hungry.

**BRIAN BLESSED!**. Hearing him talk makes my day better but the man has also lived quite the life, though I think not many people know the guy overcame a nervous breakdown at a very young age, coupled with his bombastic character it rams it home that no man is an island but we can all bounce back. Edit:corrected **BRIAN BLESSED!**

David Attenborough. I feel that this one doesn't even need explaining. Single-handedly done more to raise the profile of environmental issues than perhaps anyone on the planet. Plus hrs the nation's de facto grandfather figure.

David Attenborough has been mentioned and it might seem cliche however he created a genre of educational entertainment that has endured and has taken pains to point out the damage our species is doing. Now in his 90s he is a prominent voice in the need to improve our actions towards being sustainable in the ecosystems of the world.

Grayson Perry. He seems genuinely curious in, and understanding of, British people and all the weird things they do. Which means when you see his art you might well see a bit of yourself in it. Heâ€™s inspiring because heâ€™s so easily inspired.

Lewis Hamilton - first black F1 driver, most successful statistically speaking, funded the Hamilton commission to get more minority ethnic children as well as women in STEM fields and motorsport, comments on human rights issues. He never stops growing, pushing and build up those around him.

Dr. Helen Sharman. I'm very pleased to come from a country whose first astronaut isn't a man by default. Equality shouldn't be about women catching up, it should be about women being first 50% of the time.
His wife Philippa is also a legend. She is a psychotherapist and her book and column have taught me much about why we do the things we do in a gentle and non judgemental manner
Fun fact, Sir David Attenborough is the only person to have won BAFTAs for programmes broadcast in black & white, colour, HD, 3D, 4K and VR.

I never know what to say to celebs at these things but went up and asked him which was the hand that rocked Tyson. Gave that massive HUH HUH HUH laugh, flashed a huge smile and held up the big left fist. Lovely lovely bloke

I met him at his book signing and he laughed because I was shaking with excitement at meeting him. I said he was a real inspiration to be so honest about his struggles. Then he gave me a hug and I got masses of brownie points getting a signed book for my Mum!

Ahh I love this response! She is the best. I met her when I was at primary school when I was about 10 years old. Our teacher asked who knew her and could name her books. I reeled some off so I was able to meet her. Wish I knew where my signed book was. Was awesome her reading to us :)

Totally agree. She introduces some incredibly rough topics with such empathy and humour, and makes them relatable to her audience. Kids can recognise themselves and other people in their lives; whilst as an adult, you can go back and put your finger on *exactly* what was so fucked up - beyond the obvious - in these stories. The Illustrated Mum, Bed and Breakfast Star, and The Suitcase Kid (among others) are heartbreaking for me as a grownup with *a lot* of safeguarding training under my belt. She is the unacknowledged master of the first person voice. She manages to capture her young protagonist's personalities, without talking down to her target age group or coming across as preaching on social topics.
My daughterâ€™s idol. Sheâ€™s going to be dressing up as her on World Book Day next week (clutching the book she has of her!)
And you remain an inspiration to us all.

David Attenborough. Forefront of conservation, natural resource conservation, o-zone protection and heritage representation and conservation for the better part of a century. Truly inspirational person with a mind-set that has inspired generation after generation, and even now at age 95 has a work ethic that dwarfs people a quarter of his age.
Kevin Sinfield. Wonderful human being who pushed himself to the limits to raise money for the equally inspiring Rob Burrow who refuses to let MND take away his smile.

Mark Beaumont and Jenny Graham. Both around the globe cycling record holders, one supported in 78 days and the other completely solo and unsupported in 124 days.

Kingslee Daley, aka Akala. Football apprentice at QPR, Maths Scholar, Restaurant owner, godlike MC, Author of fiction and nonfiction, historian, political activist, all round voice of reason, Founder of the HipHop Shakespeare Theatre Company. All from a single parent family in London.

Kevin Sinfield. Great career at Leeds Rhinos, winning everything he possibly could in British Rugby League. When it came time to leave the club, rather than play for somebody else and possibly have to pay against the club he'd played all his life for, he switched codes and played Union for Yorkshire Carnegie for a while, but he's been an absolute colossus since retiring for raising awareness of motor neurone disease, raising over Â£1m running 7 marathons in 7 days, and another mil running 101 miles in 24hrs. His best friend and former teammate Burrow was diagnosed with the disease in 2019 and he's said he's not going to stop fundraising until a cure has been found. Great guy.

Martin Roberts, the legend of Homes Under the Hammer. TV, radio, books, charity appearance on Strictly. And raising a family quietly in the background. Long may his air piano grace our screens! [Martin Roberts piano](https://youtu.be/v4iNu1MRb20)

My answer is Steven Bartlett. He's a self made millionaire under 30 who struggled with schooling and is now a very humble and open person discussing his flaws. Not the most inspiring but listening to his podcasts and the guests he talks with and the quality, depth and openness of his podcasts are what I find inspiring and have helped me look at things in different ways. I recommend his diary of a CEO podcast and particularly the ones with Jimmy Carr, Ant Middleton (also a pretty inspiring character), James Smith and Jay Shetty to name a few.

The thing I love about him is how he exposes the class divide in education, but the education that happens outside the classroom that should happen in the classroom. Typically, middle class children are taught about money, debt and credit, how it works and how to make money work for you. How to save money, open a pension, about contracts, about their rights, most importantly how to have hope and feel in control of your finances. Heâ€™s like the financial Penn and Teller, lifting the curtain, to show what others already know and do, the knowledge they have been using in their social circle to their advantage, so we all can too.
Russel Howard, simply because his take on the news is the only way I can watch it at the moment without flying into a mental issue spiral.
